content: The "Federal Oil and Gas Reform Act of 1999" is also known as the "Federal Oil and Gas Royalty Management Act of 1982" which includes sanctions for violations related to federal oil and gas royalties, specifically civil penalties. Sec. 109 of the Federal Oil and Gas Reform Act of 1999 outlines royalty violations, prohibiting failure to comply with mineral leasing laws, regulations, or royalty payments. The Federal Oil and Gas Reform Act of 1999 prohibits violations related to royalty payments, including failure to comply with mineral leasing laws, regulations, or making timely royalty payments. Violations also include submitting false or misleading information regarding royalty payments. Violators are liable for penalties. The Federal Oil and Gas Reform Act of 1999 prohibits violations related to royalty payments, including failure to comply with mineral leasing laws or regulations. Violators face penalties, including triple the unpaid royalty amount plus interest, and a $25,000 civil penalty per violation per day. The Federal Oil and Gas Reform Act of 1999 imposes penalties for royalty payment violations, including triple the unpaid amount plus interest, and a $25,000 civil penalty per violation per day. Violations can be exempted if reported and corrected within 30 days. Lease administration violations include failure to notify the Secretary of designated areas. Lease administration violations involve failure to notify the Secretary of designated areas, refusal of lawful entry, inspection, or audit, and failure to promptly provide requested documents. Failure to comply with notification requirements, refusal of lawful entry, inspection, or audit, and failure to provide requested documents or timely report necessary records for lease management responsibilities. Failure to comply with notification requirements, refusal of lawful entry, inspection, or audit, and failure to provide requested documents or timely report necessary records for lease management responsibilities may result in penalties of up to $10,000 per violation per day. Theft of oil or gas without legal authority or knowingly dealing with stolen oil or gas is also punishable. Any unauthorized extraction, purchase, sale, or transportation of oil or gas can result in penalties of up to $25,000 per violation per day. Repeated violations will lead to notification and demand for compliance by the Secretary or their designee. If a person repeatedly violates regulations on oil or gas extraction, they will be notified and required to correct the violations within 30 days. Failure to comply will result in a civil penalty three times the usual amount for the violations. Any person failing to comply with a demand for correcting violations related to oil or gas extraction will face a civil penalty three times the usual amount. Additionally, repeated violations may lead to production shutdown or acquisition prohibition. The Secretary may take various actions against a person failing to comply with demands related to oil or gas leases, including shutting down production, prohibiting lease acquisition, canceling or transferring lease interests, and collecting reimbursement for costs incurred. The Secretary has the authority to take actions against individuals who fail to meet lease obligations, including shutting down production, prohibiting lease acquisition, canceling or transferring lease interests, and collecting reimbursement for incurred costs. Administrative appeals can be made within 15 days of notification of royalties or penalties owed. The Secretary has the authority to take actions against individuals who fail to meet lease obligations, including shutting down production, prohibiting lease acquisition, canceling or transferring lease interests, and collecting reimbursement for incurred costs. Any determination of royalties or penalties owed is final unless an administrative appeal is filed within 15 days. The Secretary or designee will make a final determination in accordance with regulations if an appeal is filed. The Secretary can take actions against individuals for lease violations, including shutting down production and collecting penalties. Penalties can be deducted from sums owed by the United States, and the Secretary has the authority to compromise or reduce penalties on a case-by-case basis. Notice of penalties will be served personally or by registered mail. The Secretary has the authority to compromise or reduce civil penalties, with notice served personally or by registered mail. The amount of penalty and reasons for determination must be stated on record, and judicial review is available for those who request a hearing. The Secretary can compromise or reduce civil penalties, with reasons stated on record. Judicial review is available for those aggrieved by the final order, within 90 days of issuance. The United States district court has jurisdiction over violations, with review limited to the administrative record. Failure to pay civil penalties after a final order is issued can result in legal action. After a final order making the assessment becomes final and no petition for judicial review is filed, or after a court judgment in favor of the Secretary, the court can award the assessed amount plus interest. No civil penalty under subsection (a) or (b) is applicable for failure to pay under the Mineral Leasing Act. The court can order payment of assessed amounts plus interest after the 90-day period. No civil penalty applies for failure to pay under the Mineral Leasing Act. Violations toll statutes of limitations for oil and gas leases. The Secretary or their designee can toll the statute of limitations for oil and gas leases if a person violates specific subsections until the violation is corrected or a final order is issued. A person found to have violated certain subsections must keep all records related to their oil and gas leases until released by the Secretary or until the period required by law. The person found in violation must maintain records until released by the Secretary or as required by law. Amounts received from penalties in actions related to underpayment of royalties are treated as royalties paid under the lease for mineral leasing laws and the Land and Water Conservation Fund Act of 1965. SEC. 3. SHARED CIVIL PENALTIES. Amendment to the Federal Oil and Gas Royalty Management Act of 1982 to include trebled royalties or 50% of any civil penalty.
